title: German bank robber boasts he's more intelligent than any police officer in 20-hour court speech
text:
A German bank robber delivered a 20-hour rambling closing statement in which he boasted of his career in crime, superior intelligence and excellent fitness.

Michael Jauernik, 71, was sentenced on Monday to 12 and a half years behind bars, followed by further preventative detention for three robberies, across which he stole a total €25,000 (£22,370), between 2011 and 2019.

As was his legal right, for five days, the career criminal delivered at the district court in Hamburg, what he himself described as the 'longest last word of all time'.

Michael Jauernik, 71, spoke at length for five days describing his career of crime and his perceived superior intelligence and high level of fitness

Local media reported that during his lengthy epilogue, Jauernik who committed his first bank robberies in the 1970s, appeared to justify his raids on financial institutions.

Drawing on the examples of recent high-profile banking scandals that has seen investment bankers accused of defrauding the German state of millions, he defended his actions and said: 'I didn't rob supermarkets or old women'.

Wearing a suit and dark sunglasses throughout the trial, Jauernik, who has been nicknamed Richard Gier (gier is German for greed), portrayed what he saw to be a highly intelligent image of himself.

'I am more intelligent and clever than any employee of the criminal police agency, that much is sure,' he said.

He said it was just luck that saw police capture him.

The elderly robber was described as having a narcissistic personality disorder and deemed unlikely to ever mend his ways

Jauernik also boasted he had kept himself fit ahead of his trial with three sessions of sit-ups a day and five kilometre runs.

However, on the fifth day of the 71-year-old's lengthy epilogue judge Birgit Woitas made the unusual move of cutting him off.

In light of what she described as his repeated statements and 'excessive digressions', she expressed regret she had not done it sooner.

The judge said the career criminal showed limited compassion for others and lacked insight into his actions.

At one robbery in 2017, local media reported, he shot a bank employee and blamed him for not handing over the money sooner.

'You suffer from a narcissistic personality disorder, which was on display to everyone who followed the main trial,' she said.

His appearance in a dark suit and glasses has seen the bank robber nicknamed Richard Gier (gier is German for greed) in the local media

Jauernik is notorious in Germany as a career criminal who first began robbing banks in the 1970s, The Guardian reported.

Time in jail did not set him on the straight and narrow and and in the 1980s he gained further notoriety as the 'Thursday robber' after holding up banks just before closing time on Thursdays.

The elderly man told the court he found prison to be more of an educational system rather than a place to mend his ways.

During another prison spell in Hamburg in the 1990s the robber made headlines by leading a protest against conditions and incited a riot involving around 250 other inmates.

Michael Jauernik is notorious in Germany as a career criminal who first began robbing banks in the 1970s. He is expected to spend the rest of his life behind bars

Jauernik recently began working as a night porter but returned to a bank gun in hand because he found his pension to be 'pitiful'.

In delivering his sentence Ms Woitas said it seemed unlikely that a prison sentence would change his ways.

'We are sure that you will still think it legitimate to rob banks and threaten people in 12 years' time,' she said.

Jauernik is now likely to spend the rest of his life behind bars.
